info: "私" is a common way to write "I" or "me" in Japanese, especially in formal or written contexts.
In casual speech or writing, it's often written in hiragana as "わたし".
Men might use "僕" (ぼく) or "俺" (おれ) instead, depending on the level of formality.
"友達" is commonly written in kanji to mean "friend" in Japanese.
It can refer to both male and female friends.
The term does not indicate the level of closeness of the friendship.
It combines "日本" (Japan) and "人" (people).
This word is almost always written in kanji.
"先生" is commonly written in kanji.
It is used to address teachers, professors, doctors, or anyone who is a master in their field.
It is a respectful title and can be used by students to address their instructors.
It is also used as a suffix after a person's name, like "田中先生" (Dr. Tanaka).
"日本語" means "Japanese language".
It combines "日本" (Japan) and "語" (language).
This word is almost always written in kanji.
"電話" means "telephone" in Japanese.
It is commonly written in kanji.
It can refer to both the device itself and the act of making a phone call.
"番号" means "number" and is typically written in kanji.
It is used for phone numbers, room numbers, and other numerical identifiers.
For example, "電話番号" means "phone number".
"名前" means "name" and is commonly written in kanji.
It can refer to both first names and last names.
For example, "お名前は？" means "What is your name?".
"出身" means "hometown" or "place of origin" in Japanese.
It is typically written in kanji.
It is used to refer to the place where someone is from.
"お母さん" is the polite way to refer to someone's mother.
It can be used to refer to your own mother in a polite context or someone else's mother.
In informal contexts, you might hear it as "かあさん".
"お父さん" is the polite way to refer to someone's father.
It can be used to refer to your own father in a polite context or someone else's father.
In informal contexts, you might hear it as "とうさん".
"お姉さん" is the polite way to refer to someone's older sister.
It can be used to refer to your own older sister in a polite context or someone else's older sister.
In informal contexts, you might hear "ねえさん".
"お兄さん" is the polite way to refer to someone's older brother.
It can be used to refer to your own older brother in a polite context or someone else's older brother.
In informal contexts, you might hear "にいさん".
"妹" refers to a younger sister.
It is a term used without a polite prefix.
For someone else's younger sister, you would say "妹さん" (いもうとさん).
"弟" refers to a younger brother.
It is a term used without a polite prefix.
For someone else's younger brother, you would say "弟さん" (おとうとさん).
"大学" refers to a college or university.
It is used to describe institutions of higher education.
It can also be part of compound words, such as "大学生" (college student).
This word is almost always written in kanji.
"高校" refers to high school.
It is the stage of education before college.
Students in high school are referred to as "高校生".
"学生" is a general term for student.
It can be used to refer to students of all educational levels.
"大学生" refers to a college or university student.
It combines "大学" (college) and "生" (student).
It is commonly used to identify someone's educational status.

furigana: 留学生[りゅうがくせい]
info: "留学生" refers to an international student or foreign exchange student.
It combines "留" (to stay) and "学生" (student).
It is used to describe students who study abroad.
"専攻" refers to a field of study or major in college.
It is used to describe the primary subject area a student is studying.
